When the son of the elder heard what the Buddha said, he had this thought:

He was immediately startled, frightened, worried, and his body hair stood on end. He said to the Buddha:

World-Honored One!

The Buddha told the son of the elder:

At that time, the Venerable One attained the fruit of Arhatship by himself, and having attained liberation and the fruit, he joyfully accepted liberation and single-mindedly thought:

First, leaving behind the ordinary world and attaining supreme liberation; second, benefiting others and attaining supreme liberation; third, tranquility and attaining supreme liberation; fourth, exhausting greed and attaining supreme liberation; fifth, exhausting all and attaining supreme liberation; sixth, not losing right mindfulness and attaining supreme liberation.ğŸ”½He said:
Venerable One!
If there are people who give rise to a little faith and seek liberation,
Do not see it like this, that one can attain liberation from greed, hatred, and delusion and leave behind birth and death.
Venerable One!
If there are people who give rise to a little morality and leave behind birth and death, seeking liberation without illness, affliction, or worry,
Do not see it like this, that by exhausting greed, hatred, and delusion, one can attain liberation without illness or worry.
Venerable One!
If there are people who, for the sake of fame, profit, and praise, practice tranquility and seek liberation,
Do not have this view: 'Having exhausted greed, hatred, and delusion, being free from craving and grasping, without losing right mindfulness, one attains liberation.'
Venerable Sirs!

If there are monks who abide in the precepts and attain mastery of the mind, they seek the supreme good path of nirvana, not clinging to form but abiding in the precepts, with their faculties well-tamed.

There are things that can confuse, but they cannot cause them to lose right mindfulness. The ears know sounds, the nose knows smells, the tongue knows tastes, the body knows touches, the mind knows all dharmas, and forms and other dharmas cannot confuse them, and they do not lose right mindfulness.

At that time, King Brahmadatta woke up and quickly returned to the city with his relatives and ministers.

The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

When the snake heard this, he thought:
This weasel is now experiencing this suffering and difficulty because of wanting to harm that rat. I am afraid that if he comes back empty-handed without finding food, he will definitely be eaten.
